Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Scanning Electron Microscope with EDS
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the Division of Biological and Physical Sciences at Delta State University (DSU), in Cleveland, Mississippi. The award allows the purchase of a scanning electron microscope (SEM) with an energy dispersive x-ray system (EDX) attachment. Acquiring an SEM will facilitate diverse scientific research investigations pertaining to biology, chemistry, and environmental science at DSU and will be utilized by professors and students. Assorted projects include taxonomic studies such as studying structural details of fossil pollen and spores from Jurassic, Cretaceous, and Quaternary formations throughout the United States, bacillary bands of parasitic nematodes, surface patterns of trichinelloid nematode eggs, leaf stomata and trichomes of native, invasive and naturalized species that infer information on climate change with regards to the local bottomland hardwood forests that are diminishing, and examining structural differences that are correlated to bulk chemical properties and textures of sheep wool when compared to synthetic yarns. Other projects are based on environmental inferences such as examining surface features of yeast to understand gene function in eukaryotic cells when subjected to differences in pH and temperature, analyzing caveolae both in cultured cells and in muscle tissue samples that pertain to obesity, and elemental mapping of heavy metals and absorbed contaminants that occur in local brownfields associated with agricultural and industrial sites so they can be restored for economic development. Travel costs to utilize an SEM will no longer be an issue and many laboratory experiences will be enhanced.

Obtaining an SEM will help recruit and retain faculty at DSU with expertise in specialized scientific areas. Faculty will utilize pictures they acquire from the SEM in presentations that they give at scientific meetings such as the Geological Society of America, Botanical Society of America, Southeastern Biology, and so forth. Students also will be able to utilize this instrument for various capstone projects that are associated with the undergraduate science degrees. Additionally, this instrument will be part of regular classroom curriculums in Anatomy and Physiology, Parasitology, Plant Anatomy, Environmental Chemistry, Cell Biology, and Problems in Biology. Students, therefore, will obtain valuable hands-on skills that will increase their admittance into graduate programs, medical schools, and other academic pursuits as well as become marketable in obtaining employment in scientific fields. In addition, faculty and staff from neighboring institutions such as Mississippi Delta Community College, Coahoma Community College, Mississippi Valley University and the USDA-Agricultural Research Station will be able to utilize this instrument. As a result, the entire Mississippi Delta will benefit from this acquisition and scientific literacy of this community will be greatly enhanced.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Delta State University (DSU) is a Carnegie Master’s I publicly-funded regional university located in the heart of the Mississippi Delta, an area well-known for its high rates of poverty and unemployment, and low per capita income.  As stated in DSU’s mission, “Emphasis is placed on excellence in instruction, followed by service and research, in the creation of a community of scholars.” 

A major objective of the science programs at DSU is to advance professors in their research, teaching, and service obligations. In 2014, DSU acquired a scanning electron microscope (SEM) model JSM-6010LA, manufactured by JEOL, Ltd. with an energy dispersive x-ray system (EDS). Acquisition of this instrument has enhanced several courses taught at DSU including Environmental Chemistry, Instrumental Analysis, Materials and Methods in Environmental Science, Entomology, Introduction to Polymer Science, Independent Research in Chemistry, Plant Anatomy, and Problems in Biology. This instrument has increased the success and retention of science students as well as enhanced DSU’s collaborations with neighboring institutions and federal government organizations including USDA-ARS in Stoneville, MS, the Smithsonian Institution National Museum of Natural History in Washington, DC, Auburn University in Auburn, AL, University of South Alabama in Mobile, AL, and more. Administrators use the SEM as a marketing tool to help recruit students.

A research laboratory is dedicated to the SEM and a sputter coater and critical point drier are installed in the same research lab. Numerous construction issues due to building renovations were ongoing for 16 months after its installation (Sept. 2014 – Dec. 2015). Despite this setback, eight faculty, two additional scientists, and 13 undergraduate students were trained on the SEM. Using the instrument, faculty have conducted diverse projects in biology, chemistry, and environmental science and have collaborated with other scientists. Projects investigating alginate fibers, fibroblast cells, termite mandibles, Jurassic-Quaternary palynomorphs, leaf cuticles, moth wings, soil health projects, chitosan fibers, and more have been pursued. Nineteen poster/oral presentations have been given and six websites (five Delta State University Media Highlights) were written that highlight the SEM. Four grants and some biology endowment funds were used to purchase additional equipment and repair parts.

For example, angiosperms and spores photographed from the Bucatunna and Hattiesburg Formations possess outstanding external features. There are few palynological studies that have been conducted on these Tertiary units. Dr. Baghai-Riding is the first to have looked at pollen and spore forms from these formations using the SEM. She is working with Dr. Brian Axsmith, Professor of Biology at the University of Southern Alabama, in documenting the past vegetation to help infer paleoecological assessments and vegetation during the middle Tertiary.

Dr. Schiff, from the USDA-Forest Service in Stoneville, MS along with Drs. Smithhart and Green at DSU, are analyzing heavy metals associated with termite mandibles. They are finding that the cutting edges of many termite mandibles are reinforced with manganese and zinc. Fifty to 100 termites are being mapped digitally with the EDS. Data and results from this particular pilot study are promising. Dr. Schiff also continues to use the SEM to take pictures of termite anatomy for a series of papers on termite systematics.

Dr. Tiftickjian's (2016) Plant Anatomy class became familiar with leaf epidermal features that are visible with an SEM: trichomes, stomata subsidiary cell detail, and basic epidermal cell structure. Dr. Baghai-Riding utilized these images when she taught the class during the 2017 Spring semester.

Dr. Baghai-Riding's (2017) Material and Methods in Environmental Science class determined whether jams/jellies from different areas of the United States could be correlated with the soils in which they were grown. In this study, seven, noncommercial jams and jellies were purchased from farmers’ markets in six areas. Samples included blackberry jam and muscadine jelly from Cleveland, MS, strawberry preserves from Fredericksburg, TX, grape jelly from Mills, MA, peach jam from Laurel, VA and Nampa, ID, and blue elderberry jelly from Lincoln Co., NV. Dr. Smithhart helped the students cook down the jams to an ash. The ash was analyzed using the EDS system associated with the SEM. Overall, 21 elements were noted from the seven ash samples. Her class discovered that six of the seven jams/jellies in this study had unique properties.

Dr. Hamilton was awarded two NIH MS-INBRE grants from 2015-2017 to develop novel oxidized alginate nanofibers and drug-loaded alginate- and chitosan-based electrospun nanonfibers. She collaborates with Dr. Gisela Büschle-Diller at Auburn University. Her lab is investigating the potential for natural polymer-based elecrospun nanofibers to be used as wound healing materials and whether their respective small molecule release profiles can be implemented in wound healing treatments. Her lab generated 13 oral and posters presentations that pertain to this research.

Other new projects are being developed. More students, collaborators and faculty will gain experience in using the SEM in forthcoming months.


Last Modified: 08/17/2017
Modified by: Nina Baghai-Riding

Images (1 of )
  • Students in Dr. Baghai-Riding?s 2017 Material and Method Class wanted to determine whether jams/jellies from different areas of the United States can be correlated with the soils in which they were grown. 21 elements were noted from seven jams/jellies in this study had unique properties
    Nina Baghai-Riding and her BIO 415 class
    Nina Baghai-Riding
    Locally grown fruit retains its soil signature: An elemental study of regional variation in noncommercial jams and jellies
  • Recently fossil leaves were found in the Bucatunna Formation (early Oligocene) from Monroe Co., Alabama; Dr. Baghai-Riding discovered and documented well-preserved palynomorphs from this unit. Previously this formation was regarded as a nonfossiliferous coastal/nearshore deposit.
    Nina Baghai-Riding, Brian Axsmith and Kendal Davis
    Public Domain
    Nina Baghai-Riding
    An analysis of a palynological sample from the Bucatunna Formation
  • Heavy metals including zinc and manganese are appearing in termite mandibles.
    Kendal Davis, Dalvin Williams and Ben Scrivener
    Nina Baghai-Riding
    Termite mandible showing heavy mandible distribution
  • This poster details the process of optimizing electrospinning parameters of alginate- and chitosan-based nanofibers and the incorporation of the small drug molecule ciprofloxacin. SEM images of each electrospun sample are taken and analyzed to aid in the optimization process.
    Sharon K. Hamilton and Kathryn Penton
    Nina Baghai-Riding
    Progress towards drug-loaded natural polymer-based nanofibers for wound healing and drug delivery
  • A lower epidermis leaf section of Tradescantia depicting guard cells, a stomata pore and subsidiary cells.
    John Tiftickjian
    Copyrighted
    Nina Baghai-Riding
    Stomata of Tradescantia
  • Fine details of moth wing scales are visible on this scanning electron microscope photograph.
    John Tiftickjian
    Copyrighted
    Nina Baghai-Riding
    Moth wing scales
